tn.text: Translate this man's name the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:15:11|15:12]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"12,000 men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"begin to"
"come to"
These words mean basically the same thing and are used together to emphasize how weak David was. AT: "weak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Here the word "fear" can be expressed with the adjective "afraid." AT: "will surprise him and make him afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: I will attack only the king
tn.text: It is implied that he intends to kill the king. This can be stated clearly. AT: "I will kill only the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to all of the people who were with David. AT: "bring back all of the people who were with him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: like a bride coming to her husband
tn.text: Here Ahithophel speaks of the peoples' happiness by comparing it to a bride's happiness. AT: "and they will come happily, like a bride is happy when she comes to her husband" or "and they will come happily" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This means to have peace or to live peacefully. AT: "live peacefully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This refers to being under the king's authority. AT: "under your authority" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Translate this man's name the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:15:32|15:32]].
Translate this man's name the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:15:11|15:12]].

tn.ref: they are like a bear robbed of her cubs
tn.text: The anger of the soldiers here is being compared to that of a mother bear who cubs are taken from her. AT: "they are angry, like a mother bear whose cubs have been take from her" or "they are very angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
a large furry animal that walks on four legs and has sharp claws and teeth
This means that his has fought in many battles and knows well the ways of war. AT: "has fought in many battles" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here this word is used to draw someone's attention to what is said next. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
a deep hole in the ground
This is another place he may be hiding. AT: "or hidden in some other place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: when some of your men have been killed
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "when his soldiers kill some of your men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: A slaughter has taken place among the soldiers who follow Absalom
tn.text: The noun "slaughter" means an event where many people are brutally killed. This can be expressed as a verb. AT: "Many of the soldiers who follow Absalom have been slaughtered" or "The enemy soldiers have killed many of the soldiers who follow Absalom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: whose hearts are like the heart of a lion
tn.text: Here the soldiers are refers to by their "hearts." Also, their strong bravery is compared to that of a lion's. AT: "who are as brave as lions" or "who are very brave" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: that all Israel should be gathered together to you
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. Also, the all of the soldiers in Israel are referred to here as "all Israel." AT: "that you should gather together all of the Israelite soldiers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This phrase means from the northern border of Israel to the southern border. AT: "from the whole nation of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

tn.ref: as numerous as the sands that are by the sea
tn.text: This is an exaggeration where all the grains of sand on a beach are compared to the number of Israelite soldiers. AT: "so many that they can barely be counted" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: that you go to battle in person
tn.text: The phrase "in person" means to go yourself and not send someone else instead. AT: "then lead them yourself into battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means to purposefully go to where he is and then to attack. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: we will cover him as the dew falls on the ground
tn.text: Absalom's army is described as covering David's army like the dew covers the ground in the morning. AT: "we will overwhelm and completely defeat David's army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
the fog or misty cloud of water that can fall onto the ground during the night, covering the ground and leaving it wet in the morning

tn.ref: We will not leave even one of his men ... alive
tn.text: This negative sentence is used for emphasis and can be stated in a positive form. AT: "We will kill every one of his men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
Both these words refer to David. AT: "David himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])
This refers to Israel's soldiers, not to all of Israel. AT: "then all of our soldiers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: will bring ropes to that city and we will drag it into the river
tn.text: This means that the soldiers would tear down the city walls and drag the pieces to river. AT: "will destroy the city and drag the stones to the river with ropes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: until there is no longer even a small stone found there
tn.text: This is an exaggeration to describe how completely they will destroy the city. The would not literally sweep away every small stone from the city. AT: "until the city is completely destroyed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Translate this man's name the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:15:32|15:32]]. Archite is the name of a people group.
Translate this man's name the same as you did in  [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:15:11|15:12]].

tn.ref: the rejection of Ahithophel's good advice
tn.text: The word "rejection" can be expressed with the verb "reject." AT: "for the men of Israel to reject Ahithophel's good advice" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
To "bring" something on someone means to cause it to happen to them. AT: "to cause a disaster to happen to Absalom" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Translate these men's name the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:15:24|15:24-25]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: in such and such a way
tn.text: This phrase, meaning "like this," refers to what Ahithophel advised Absalom earlier in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:17:01|17:1-3]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
A ford is a shallow part of a river where people can walk across. The Arabah is the land along both sides of the Jordan River.
This means to make sure that you do something. AT: "be sure to" or "make sure that you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: the king will be swallowed up
tn.text: Here the king and his people being killed is describes as if they were "swallowed" by their enemy. AT: "the king will be killed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Translate these men's names the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:15:27|15:27]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

Here the "message" is spoken of as coming to them, when really it is the woman who came to then bringing the message. AT: "When she brought them a message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"one time"

tn.ref: So Jonathan and Ahimaaz went away
tn.text: It is implied that they found out that the young man had told Absalom about them being there. This can be stated clearly. AT: "Jonathan and Ahimaaz found out what the young man had done, so they went away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
These are the name of places, both near Jerusalem. Bahurim is a small town. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"they lowered themselves and hid"
"the man's wife"
Translate these men's names the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:15:27| 15:27]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"It happened." This phrase marks the next event in the storyline. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
Here "the water" refers to the Jordan River. AT: "cross quickly over the river" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: has given such and such advice
tn.text: The idiom "such and such" is used in the place of information that is already know by the reader. Here it refers to what Ahithophel advised Absalom in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:17:01|17:1-3]]. This information can be stated clearly. AT: "has advised that Absalom send him with an army to attack you now" (See:  [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: By morning daylight not one of them had failed to cross over the Jordan
tn.text: This negative sentence is used to emphasize that they all crossed the river. It can be stated in a positive form. AT: "By morning daylight every one of them had crossed over the Jordan" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
"knew" or "realized"

tn.ref: his advice had not been followed
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Absalom had not followed his advice" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
to place a blanket or small leather seat on a donkey or horse for the rider to sit on
He prepared for his death by telling his family what to do after he died. AT: "he prepared for his death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"And this is how"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "they buried him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Translate the names of these places the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:02:08|2:8-9]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of men. See how you translated Joab and Zeruiah (Joab's mother) in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:02:12|2:13]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

This word means that the person is descended from Ishmael. Some versions say "Israelite" here. See the footnote. You may want to choose the word that is used in the majority language Bible in your area.
These are the names of women. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This phrase is used to introduce the next event in the storyline. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
These are the names of cities or places. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of people groups. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
A mat is something soft to sleep on, and a blanket is a cloth covering for warmth.
Flour is crushed grain made into powder and used to make bread.
"cooked"
seeds that are cooked and eaten
a kind of seed that is cooked and eaten
milk that has soured and  become solid
in need of water or some other drink
